makers.displaydate: born 1973, Tehran, Iran; active Brooklyn, NY
makers.displaymaker: Bahar Behbahani, born 1973, Tehran, Iran; active Brooklyn, NY

texts.textentryhtml: River Goddess is based on Behbahani’s study of garden plans drawn by the Princeton University architectural historian Donald Newton Wilber (1907–1997). A scholar of Persian gardens, Wilber was also an architect of the 1953 US CIA–led coup d’état of the Iranian prime minister Mohammad Mosaddeq. The geometric patterns and palette of blues, greens, and gold in this painting echo the intricate symmetries of ceramic cut-tile mosaics that characterize the architecture of Isfahan, Iran. Located on ancient trade routes between Europe and Asia, Isfahan was rebuilt in the early seventeenth century by the Safavid Empire (1501–1736) as a grand Persian charbagh—an ornate quadrangular landscape designed around a central fountain that recalls the Qur’anic gardens of Paradise. The artist cites star maps from Islamic manuscripts, revealing the influence of Arabic astronomy; two lines of Chinese calligraphy in the lower-left quadrant evoke East Asian ink-brush painting at the Persian court.
Bahar Behbahani, the artist, New York, New York, consigned; to [Trotter and Scholer, New York, New York], sold; to Princeton University Art Museum, 2022.

displaymaker: Bahar Behbahani, born 1973, Tehran, Iran; active Brooklyn, NY
